column1: The Church of the Intercession of the Holy Virgin (Russian: Храм Покрова Пресвятой Богородицы) is a Russian Orthodox church in Konstantinovsk
column3: Russia that belongs to the Diocese of Volgodnosk and was built in 1912 on the project of architect Pyotr Studenikin.

column1: The Church of the Intercession of the Holy Virgin began to be constructed in spring of 1907 on the project of architect Pyotr Studenikin. The building was completed in 1912.

column2: the church building was turned into a granary. During World War II
column3: when Konstantinovsk was occupied by Wehrmacht forces
column4: it was used as an ammunition depot. Soon it was handed over to the Orthodox community (which was officially registered in 1945) again. Liturgies continued to be held there until the late 1960s. In the early 1960s
column5: the church was renovated with its interior being redecorated. Later
column6: it was closed again and housed a gym which was functioning there until the late 1980s.

column2: the Church of the Intercession was transferred to the Russian Orthodox Church again and liturgies have been held there since then.

column1: The Church of the Intercession is built in an Eclecticist style with Byzantine
column2: Italian Renaissance and Russian Revival architecture elements being presented. The Intercession Church is built of bricks. The external brickwork of the walls is left unplastered
column3: and that is an important element of the facade decoration. Today
column4: the church is one of the highest buildings in Konstantinovsk
column5: for the majority of town buildings only have one story.
